63.18.text: Hello, and welcome to a show called Romania Through Their Eyes!

67.06.text:
The reason for this show is a seeming contradiction in 
 behavior between two groups of people in Romania:

73.33.text: the foreigners, and the Romanians. The latter want to leave the country,

78.76.text: they're looking for any opportunity to find a life somewhere else.

83.13.text:
The former are drawn to it. They want to visit it, they 
 want to spend time here, and quite a few of them

94.03.text:
I'm going to try and shed some light on the matter with 
 this show. It's a series of interviews with foreigners,

101.03.text:
people who've spent a significant amount of time in the 
 country, know it well, and want to share

108.09.text:
I'm going to ask each person a standard set of 
 questions. While they may be the same, their answers

115.08.text:
are going to be different, and may be surprise you. And 
 who knows -- one can only pray -- they

122.01.text:
may also end up enlightening those currently running 
 the country, and helping to focus

126.67.text: their attention on issues of international relevance.

130.59.text: I hope you'll enjoy the show, and join me for each new episode!

135.26.text:
Today's interview is with Tom Lovelock. He's originally from the UK, 
 but he came to Romania by way of Qatar.

143.73.text: He moved to the country with his wife six months ago.

148.98.text:
Right. My name is Tom Lovelock, I'm from the 
 United Kingdom, I'm 62 years old,

155.13.text:
and we came here from Qatar in the Middle East, where 
 we lived for five years, and we've been here

162.81.text:
We got here on August the 9th, 2010. We 
 live in Bucharest. We're not passing through,

169.34.text:
we're here to live permanently, because my wife 
 is working in Bucharest. I am retired.

174.71.text:
For over thirty years I've sold all sorts of cars in the 
 UK. Before that, I was a young policeman in London.

183.75.text:
I spent six and a half years as a policeman in 
 London. Which kind of gives you a good grounding.

189.73.text:
I went from policeman to car dealer... There probably isn't anybody 
 in the whole world that would trust me.

195.63.text:
All I've got to add is estate agent or financial advisor to 
 the list, and then I'm certainly going to hell.

201.50.text:
It's a lot different, obviously, from Qatar in the Middle East. For a 
 start, we can walk out the door and get a beer.

210.89.text: And women don't walk around with veils and stuff like that...

215.62.text:
Qatar is a very, very closed society. Everybody used to say, 
 oh, you lived in the Middle East, it must be

220.09.text:
very glamorous. But (people from England enjoy this), it's like 
 living in Milton Keynes, but without the

225.03.text:
interesting bits. Everybody lives in a compound, you mix with the same 
 people all the time, it just drives you crazy.

231.09.text:
We did it for five years. We came to Romania 
 because we wanted an European style of life,

236.31.text: but without paying German or Italian prices. Romania suits us perfectly.

241.99.text:
It's got a good cost of living, we live well, we 
 enjoy ourselves here, and I just like the place.

250.71.text: We find it exhilarating, living in Romania!

254.60.text:
We like the way of life -- me, because of my age, I'm 
 sort of a child of the 60s and 70s in London,

261.45.text:
everybody remembers about swinging London and stuff like that... 
 As Bucharest is at the moment,

266.54.text:
it reminds me very much of how things were in those 
 days. Okay, your city's a little bit crumbly,

272.25.text:
and it could do with a nice clean-up, a bit of a 
 tidy-up, but it's an interesting, fun place to live.

278.25.text:
If I was 30 years younger, I'd have even more fun 
 here, although I probably wouldn't be married for much

283.07.text: longer if I did that -- you see what I mean...

286.53.text:
I just like the place. You can walk around, and 
 you couldn't walk around in Qatar, for instance, because

292.69.text: with the heat, everybody goes by car, you can't walk anywhere.

295.46.text:
The area where we live [now], there's a tube station 
 (a metro station) just down the road.

299.64.text: We have shops, banks, cafes... Everything we need is within walking distance.

304.18.text:
When we go into the center of the town, it's 
 four stops on the metro, and we're there.

309.84.text:
All these things haven't been part of our lives for many years, 
 and it's just like living back in London, back in

315.88.text:
the old days. It's even almost as cheap, because the cost of 
 living is (from our point of view), really, really,

323.21.text:
really good. You should probably put your prices 
 up a little, but not much.

328.28.text:
We like the local markets, we like the local shops. The ladies 
 in our local shop are teaching me how to

335.23.text:
speak Romanian, because they shout at me when I 
 don't actually say the right word.

339.01.text:
so I can say things like butter -- but I'm not going to say 
 it now. I can say egg, and I can say bread,

345.61.text:
and I'm not going to say any of them now, 
 but I can say them in the shops.

348.14.text:
We like living near Herastrau Park, because we 
 go quite frequently to the lake.

354.50.text:
None of these things we've seen for years. In the Middle 
 East, the water we see is the Persian Gulf.

359.61.text:
And it just looks like a sea, with sand -- 
 because we got a lot sand [there].

364.01.text:
I like the metro. I like the metro a LOT, because I used 
 to travel all the time, when I was younger, in London,

372.71.text:
you always went by what we called the tube, and I 
 missed the tube, because traveling and driving through Bucharest

380.06.text:
you've got to be crazy to try and do it. I don't know why you 
 don't get a lot of road rage. In the UK we get a lot

385.52.text:
of road rage. Nobody seems to have road rage here 
 -- probably because everybody, when they're driving,

389.98.text:
is too busy on their phone, or drinking a cup of coffee, 
 or talking to the guy in the car next door,

395.13.text:
to actually get angry about anything, which is probably 
 why you get so many traffic jams.

398.01.text:
I had a guy drive me somewhere this morning, and he 
 was drinking a cup of coffee, smoking a cigarette,

405.54.text:
on his mobile phone, and reading a map, while we're 
 going along some road at 80 km/h.

410.36.text:
So, stop doing that, because sooner or later, the cigarette's going 
 to go out, you're going to spill the coffee,

418.24.text:
or you're going to crash the car, which is 
 the worst thing you can possibly do.

421.63.text:
Also, you're probably going to run over a dog if you're not 
 looking out the window, because there's a lot of them

430.28.text:
When we got here, there were two things everybody said were going 
 to happen as soon as we got to Romania.

434.60.text:
First of all, you're going to get ripped off by a 
 taxi driver at Otopeni Airport. The guy was fantastic.

440.99.text:
He forgot to charge us half the fare, waited for us for about 
 half an hour because we went to the wrong hotel,

447.37.text:
didn't put the meter on, and far from ripping us off, we 
 had to put some more money in his pocket,

451.02.text:
because he wanted to drive away with the equivalent of about 
 5 euros for nearly 2 hours of his time.

457.41.text:
There's a few hoods that hang around at Baneasa [Airport]. You 
 can tell these guys, because they jump on you.

462.59.text:
They're dressed the same as the security guards at Baneasa 
 Airport. Avoid them, because they try and

469.04.text:
strong-arm you into the back of some beat up old thing, and 
 they go wherever you don't want to go, and then

475.23.text:
they'll try to... but apart from that, they're easy to 
 spot. But Otopeni [taxi drivers], they're great people.

482.62.text:
The other thing they told us was [about] the wild dogs. 
 The first time we walked out of the hotel room

488.62.text:
we were worried about the wild dogs. But they 
 weren't wild, they were all asleep.

492.15.text:
You've got the wild sleeping dogs of Bucharest, and 
 these guys are just hanging around,

495.89.text:
the place, getting fatter, 'cause everybody feeds them. So those 
 two stories -- we just kicked them

504.94.text:
We traveled all around Europe, and because we were coming 
 from the Middle East and were going to live

507.84.text:
in what we thought was a cold country, as we traveled 
 around Europe, we divested ourselves of all our hot-weather

513.83.text: clothes. We threw away our shorts, our t-shirts, sandals, threw them all away.

519.59.text:
When we got here, we got off the plane wearing sweaters, 
 boots and jeans, and it's 35 degrees temperature.

526.07.text:
So we had to go down to Baneasa [Mall] and spend 
 a fortune buying loads of hot-weather clothes again,

530.97.text: then it got cold again. Thank you...

533.62.text:
There are some interesting things. In Bucharest, in the town center, 
 if you spent some money cleaning up the

542.63.text:
buildings... You know the Arc de Triomphe -- you claim it's 
 a foot higher than the real one, they're

547.90.text:
they're telling you it's not. But all these other buildings 
 you got, clean them up, because they

553.73.text:
would look gorgeous, they would absolutely look fantastic. They're 
 just all grimy and horrible now, even

559.65.text:
the flats, just clean them up, you'll be amazed at the 
 difference you make. Fill in, spend the money

565.34.text:
on the streets. The place is beautiful. Herastrau Park in 
 the fall, in the autumn, it made New England

572.77.text:
look drab, it really did. It was fantastic! 
 It looked great in the snow.

578.60.text:
It's a good tourist thing. Everybody would like to think 
 that Vlad Dracula actually was born in the house

584.54.text:
where you're dining, but he can't have been born in 80 
 places at once. He can't have lived absolutely everywhere.

592.83.text:
For a start, he's not supposed to have lived. We think he's one 
 of the undead. It turns out, not only is he not

598.31.text:
undead, but he's been born 85 times, all around Transilvania. 
 Everybody's got a relative that knew him.

604.69.text:
Or an uncle, or an auntie, that he was related to. Okay... 
 push it, but you're pushing it a bit too far.

612.29.text:
It's like the Germans saying that everybody used to know 
 Hitler, that "he wasn't a bad bloke when

616.84.text:
we knew him". But he was, he really was, honestly. Now 
 that's why the Second World War broke out.

623.36.text:
A friend of mine did eight years research on why the 
 second world war broke out. What was the main reason?

632.23.text:
After eight years research, it turns out that Hitler was 
 a right bastard, and that was it.

639.18.text: You're going to have to do a lot of editing there, aren't you?

641.99.text:
There's a certain sort of macho image that Romanian guys 
 like to give -- like your security guards.

648.49.text:
who work for the security companies, with all the paramilitary 
 gear that they all wear, with the big

652.99.text:
nightsticks, and the big boots, and they're all glaring at 
 people every time you walk past them.

659.14.text:
The fact of the matter is that they're just private 
 security guards, they can't do anything to you.

662.12.text:
Alright, they can stop you if you climb over the fence or 
 something, they might be able to stop you, but

666.23.text: there's nothing they can do, so what is with all the tough guy gear?

670.78.text:
Landscape gardening is the big coming thing in Romania. Believe 
 me, all the rich people here think they need

677.63.text:
They don't. But nevertheless you can charge them for 
 a new garden. They have to have somewhere

684.41.text: for the security guy to stand, so they need a garden.

687.16.text:
Like everybody else, no one likes your government. Sorry about 
 that folks, but nobody likes them. Mind you,

695.81.text:
we don't like our government much, either. But you need 
 to do something about your government. When they

701.50.text:
collect taxes, they're supposed to spend them on running the 
 country, not on new Mercedes Benz and

705.68.text:
and leather jackets. Maybe you should ask them 
 about that at your next election.

710.53.text:
We were driving through Bucharest the other day, and all of 
 sudden, [we saw] a great big huge convoy of black

718.76.text:
BMWs and Mercedes goes flying by us. I don't know if 
 it was the president, or the prime minister,

723.35.text:
or whoever. Wherever he was going, he made me late, 
 and I think I'm more important than him.

729.43.text: So I don't like being late.

734.34.text:
You could do with a bit more forceful [attitude] than okay, 
 you can't get anything done, this is Romania...

743.55.text:
What can you do... Of course you can do it! That's why you 
 got the vote! That's why you're in the European Union!

749.32.text:
So you can do all these things! You don't have to shrug 
 your shoulders and go "Oh, there's nothing we can

755.44.text:
do about it, it's them, it's us"... Of course you can 
 do something about it! If you're not getting paid

759.87.text:
enough money, you can go on strike. If you're being fooled 
 around by the local people, because they're not

765.63.text:
clearing the street, then complain to someone, and keep complaining 
 until he does it. And they will actually

770.49.text:
do it in the end. And make the people who get your money 
 spend it on what they're supposed to be spending it.

775.76.text:
And not new houses up in Pipera, and Mercedez Benz... Although 
 Jaguars are okay, 'cause I used to work for

781.53.text: Jaguar. So you can spend it on Jaguars, but not Mercedes Benz.

785.32.text:
What I don't like about a lot that goes on in this part of 
 the world -- not just Romania, but they get it in Hungary,

793.70.text:
Bulgaria, and other sorts of places, is that your authorities, 
 and especially people like your police, they're not

800.93.text:
working for the people, they're not doing what they're supposed 
 to be doing, which is protecting you,

804.76.text:
and stopping your getting robbed in the streets, and stuff like that. 
 You don't have a police force whose job it is

811.39.text:
to protect the government, or keep the government in power. It's not 
 their job. Their job is to walk around the streets

815.04.text:
making sure people don't steal your car, and your wallet, and 
 making you feel safe, and you should remember that,

821.01.text:
and you should go out and remind people that 
 that's what they should be doing.

825.49.text:
Your police force could do with nicer uniforms. Nobody's joining 
 the police force here because they get a smart

831.07.text:
uniform which attracts the girls. The guys are all walking around 
 in polyester. And they need new cars as well.

836.36.text:
I mean, have you seen the little tiny police cars? Everybody 
 else is driving around in BMWs, and these guys

842.85.text:
are trying to chase around in diesel Dacias, and it's not 
 going to work, believe me, it will not work.

847.06.text:
But they do have guns, which I suppose makes 
 up a little bit of the difference.

851.99.text:
Yeah, I suppose if you come and live here, obviously you do 
 your research before you come here. Most of the blogs

860.71.text:
and things are free, they'll tell you how much you should be 
 paying to rent an apartment, but the thing to do

865.87.text:
when you get here is to just take it easy. Don't 
 walk around with your hand on your wallet, thinking

870.52.text:
you're in a foreign country. All of the stories that you read 
 in a lot of the magazines, they're just not true.

876.16.text:
It's just a normal European country, everybody's just trying to 
 get by, nobody is going to pick your pocket

884.15.text:
every time you're going to get on the metro, or walk 
 across Piata Victoria, it's just not going to happen,

889.19.text:
no more than it's going to happen in any other city in 
 the world. So just get off the plane, don't worry

894.95.text:
about the cab driver, they've all got the price of the cab 
 written on the side of the door, if you don't like

898.10.text:
the price, then don't get in the thing. Catch a bus, they're 
 only across the street. Nobody here is looking to rip

903.35.text:
you off, the way people say they're to rip you 
 off, except the government, obviously, because they're

907.51.text: ripping everybody off. And I going to get deported for this?

914.59.text:
One of the things I didn't like is that you get 
 pounced on by your own countrymen in this country.

921.09.text: British guys, ex-patriots, the Americans probably get it, the Canadians [too].

924.94.text:
"Oh, come to the expat bar, or come to the British 
 pub..." They'll go to these places, all mix together,

928.33.text:
and these guys, the first thing they'll do, is rip you off 
 for money, because they're all trying to sell you

933.42.text:
finance packages, or pension packages, or persuade you that 
 you need a British advisor, otherwise

938.49.text:
you'll never find your way around Romania. It's like you've 
 got a Labrador and a white stick.

944.77.text:
They think you're blind. In this day and age, even I at 62, 
 can get on the internet, and find out where my local

950.86.text:
police station is, where the post office is, where I can go 
 and rent a house, where I have to register because

957.64.text:
I'm a UK citizen. All these things you can find out 
 for yourselves, you don't have to give some guy

963.12.text:
350 euros to get your car registered, you can go down 
 to RAR and do it yourself. It's easy.

969.35.text:
So when you go to these places, don't give anybody 
 any money. Alternatively, you do the job

974.87.text:
and get money off them. At least you get the 
 satisfaction of putting the money in your pocket.

980.16.text: Another good idea is [to] get yourself a good lawyer, a decent lawyer.

984.87.text:
It's the paperwork -- it's not so much the legal side of 
 it -- there's a lot of paperwork in this country,

990.51.text:
and they know the paperwork, and what you're supposed to sign. 
 So if you get a decent lawyer, you can

995.53.text:
always find me, or get on the website, and I will tell you 
 who are good lawyers, but don't go to the people in

1001.11.text:
the English pubs, because they will rip you off. Get yourself 
 a decent lawyer, because they give you good advice

1005.49.text: and tell you which form to fill out so as things get done.

1007.54.text:
And us guys, when we come here, instead of just turning 
 up and just joining in and doing what everybody

1013.42.text:
else does, we should show our best. If you're going to 
 come over and do business in Romania, don't turn up

1018.98.text:
and just start ripping people off, or open up some 
 daft internet company, or financial services company,

1026.44.text:
or some idiotic thing which is just there to line your 
 pockets at other people's expense. Come here and

1031.25.text:
put something in. Contribute! Show these people, show Romania how 
 we like to do things, because that's how

1039.94.text:
they like to do things as well. People will trust you if 
 you trust them. If you just turn up and start complaining

1046.62.text:
about everything, and roaming about the place going "I'll only 
 shop at Carrefour", or stuff like that,

1053.75.text:
then you're never going to find out about Romania -- same as 
 we know guys who never know anything about Qatar.

1059.62.text:
I know people who've lived in Qatar, on the same compound, 
 for five years, and the only time they've actually

1065.25.text:
been in the city is to drive down to Carrefour, and 
 down to the same shop, and come back again.

1069.83.text:
They've never actually bothered to go into the bazaars, or the 
 souqs, or anything like that. They don't speak

1074.39.text:
a word of Arabic, they never mix with anybody, and every year you 
 can actually time to the date -- they all turn

1082.47.text:
up for the same quiz night, the same parties, the 
 same New Year's celebrations, same people, all there.

1086.99.text:
The "in crowd", and they know nothing about the country that 
 they're living in. Find out about the country

1092.14.text:
you're living in. It's not different from the country you used 
 to live in, it's the same. You know, everybody's got

1096.95.text:
to be somewhere, you just happen to be in Romania. That's all 
 there is to it. You don't feel any different, your

1102.30.text:
skin doesn't turn another color, you don't turn green, or grow 
 stalks out your head when you turn up,

1106.99.text:
you're just some place else. And be normal. 
 Do what you normally would do.

1113.07.text: And let go of my cat!

1118.12.text:
My cat is annoying some lady here, I'll put that in there, and 
 he'll appear on camera in just a little bit, his name

1124.61.text:
is Peter, he's from Arabia, so he's a Muslim. Okay, here you go... 
 Alright, this is Peter the cat, he came with us from

1134.88.text:
Arabia, and he cost me 1,500 euros to get him here. He flew 
 here via Amsterdam. I don't know if he had a layover

1144.54.text:
or not in Amsterdam. I wish I'd have flown via Amsterdam 
 myself. I've been there, it's a nice place.

1149.57.text:
Don't go to the Irish pubs! Why are there 27 Irish pubs 
 in Bucharest? There aren't 27 Irish pubs in Dublin!

1157.57.text:
Everybody goes to Irish pubs. Open some other sort of bar. Go 
 to a Romania bar! Go to a Romanian restaurant!

1165.94.text:
Why would you want to come all this way to live 
 in another country, and then end up drinking Guinness,

1170.75.text:
talking to some bloke about football, in an English or an 
 Irish pub? Why would you want to do that?

1176.60.text:
You've wasted your money! You might as well have stayed at home. 
 Apart from the fact that beer's about a third

1180.95.text:
of the price... But apart from that, there's no reason to do it. 
 There's no reason why you would want to do it.

1185.90.text:
I know a guy who's a colleague of my wife's. I'm not 
 going to mention his name... No, I'm definitely going to

1192.51.text:
mention it, because he'll watch this, but the guy never goes 
 out anywhere. He never turns up for anything.

1199.96.text:
He knows nothing about anybody, and he just sits there. When I 
 spoke to him, he said "I don't like Romania".

1207.93.text:
I said, what don't you like? He says, "The dogs bark at 
 night". I said, move your bedroom or shut the window.

1212.27.text:
And he said, "Yeah, I can't stand it. The dogs 
 bark at night, and the streets are dirty."

1216.73.text: Well, so what... "And I can't drive my car around 'cause there's potholes..."

1220.81.text:
I said, did you not read a book, did you not get on 
 the Internet, did you not find out about the country

1226.23.text:
you're going to live in before you hopped on a plane, or 
 in your case, in your car, and drove here?

1232.03.text:
Just find out about the place, and then you're not going to be 
 surprised. I mean, if you don't like the roads here,

1237.00.text:
try the roads in Qatar, which disappear. It rains every three years, 
 and then the road is gone. They have to put

1244.33.text:
another road up, because they just lay the road on the sand, 
 and when it rains, water goes under the road,

1248.90.text:
you got no road! You think the roads are bad here, 
 try somewhere like Ethiopia. I worked there for a while

1254.37.text:
as well. I mean, there are no roads. If you want to 
 get around anywhere safely, go by helicopter, 'cause that's the

1259.68.text:
only way you're going to get around. So don't do these 
 things. Just turn up, get off your plane,

1267.75.text:
and live a normal life. And you'll get on just fine. Absolutely. And 
 when you go in, you'll ask people, and they will

1275.40.text:
tell you, they'll advise you, they will help you. They won't 
 particularly try and rip you off, no more than

1279.09.text:
anybody else would try and rip you off, and you'll 
 enjoy life here immensely, especially if you're young.

1283.64.text:
This is a young person's country. What else should you 
 do when you come to live in Romania?

1291.47.text:
If you're under 30, I would actually buy yourself a pair 
 of blinkers, because the women here are hot!

1296.88.text:
Believe me, they are! These are the best looking women in 
 Europe, bar none, including Italy, and I've been to

1305.24.text:
Italy a lot as well. They are fantastic -- they are 
 fantastic-looking people! So if you're under 30, you are going

1311.33.text:
to have a good time if you come to live here. But you will 
 end up with a large extended family in about 3 months.

1316.01.text: And remember, all these girls have got brothers and fathers.

1326.25.text:
I can't think of any other reason why you 
 wouldn't come to live in Romania, really.

1329.48.text:
I think it's a fantastic place, I really, really -- we've grown to 
 like it, it's like being young again, it really is.

1338.45.text: And the prices, everything is right.

1340.48.text:
You've got to integrate and live in with it, and 
 become part of the country you're living in.

1347.04.text:
You've got your British friends, but we've got --- since we've 
 lived here, we've had people come to visit us

1353.05.text:
from Scotland, we've had people come to visit from Canada, 
 from Qatar, somebody's going to come and see

1360.31.text:
us from Nepal. We know people all over the world. We've got 
 friends in Mexico. When you work in the circuits we

1366.49.text:
work in, you know people all over the world. And 
 you've got things like Skype and Facebook. Nowadays,

1372.07.text:
everybody's a neighbor. Everybody sort of lives next door, you don't 
 need to think "I'm in a foreign country",

1377.97.text:
Johnny-foreigner, and all the rest of it, because it's just not 
 so anymore. The only barrier is the language barrier

1384.36.text:
and Romanian's a pretty easy language. If you speak a little 
 Italian, or a little Spanish, or any kind of romance

1391.68.text:
language, then you'll get on just fine learning Romanian. It's pretty easy 
 to pick up. And if not, do what the

1397.75.text:
British thing, just shout at them in English, that 
 always works.  Well, it does, doesn't it?

1404.11.text:
An Englishman just shouts at people, and everybody speaks 
 English. You shout long enough, and

1407.39.text:
